page.lettertext:
fol.33r
[To my]
L. Trea
s
May it please yo
r
good L. there hath no occasyon fallen
to write unto yo
r
L. since I sent yo
u
my last,
e 10 of this
moneth, onely this is asmu ch as I can thinke to be worthy
of yo
r
L. knowledge that wheras heertofore the Province of
Gueldres
upon pretence of unability, hath contributed nothing
in a maner to
e g
na
l meanes for the mainten
a
ce of these
warres, wee are in good hope that for the good successe of
the laste sommers
s
vice in freeing the Velue & taking in
of
Nieumegen
w
th
oth
r
places adjoyning, they will be drawen
to condiscend to 1000
li
by
e moneth, w
ch
I also think wilbe
augmented by
e accesse of
e Imposte of
e foresaid places.
The most of
e Deputies of
e
g
na
l states
are arrived
heer already, but
e extremity of
e frost &
e hardnes of
the wether doth stay the coming of the rest. By reason wh
r
[of]
there ys nothing yet proposed, nor no answere yet conceav[ed]
to
e motion int
e
ded by
e
Em
o
rs
Ambassado
r
. It should
seme by a l
re
of
e Gouverno
r
of
Bruges,
w
ch
hath b[ene]
lately intercepted that upon
e Embassado
rs
advertisement
they are in some hope to bring this contrey to a treaty.
It may be
adventure that there was never no such matter
written by
e Embassado
rs
, but whatsoever hath bin written
I see not wh
r
uppon he should take
e least occasyon to putt
him self in that hope. For I am fully
swaded that his
answere wilbe such. as he will wishe he had not taken
this voyage in hand. Heere ys nothing now but silence
astouching those affaires, every man expecting when
e states
will assemble. As I have bin required by
e
LL.
of
e
Councel I have
cured a g
na
l muster of all her
Ma
t
forces
by
e states Commissaries: w
ch
was passed long ago but theyr
officers are so slow in making their certificat
that as yet
wee do want the rolls of
Ostend,
Albeit wee are adv
r
tised
that
e garrison there was mustered the last moneth. Those
excepted all
e rest are consigned to
e hand
of M
r
Wilkes
: and assoone as those are come they shalbe copied [in]
like manner & sent p
nt
ly after. I was willed by the LL.
of
e Councel to deale w
th
the states in her Ma
t
name, [for]
the passing of
e said muster, & for the like every moneth
or as often as they see cause. Howbeit I remembred
theyr Lordships in my answere of
e old disagreement [between]
fol.33v
her Ma
ty
&
e States about
e allowance of
e D[ead paies]
& certain other point
to w
ch
they never yelded. In [which]
respect I was
swaded, that if by order from her [Majestie]
the mustering of
e English band
were left to theyr off[icers]
consydering they will never passe the Dead paies in th[eir]
muster rolles, it might prove unto her Ma
ty
ve[ry]
p
r
judiciall. Wheruppon for that I found that I
could of my self, & for such p
r
tences, as I signif[ied]
then entreat this councel for
e p
nt
to a g
na
l m[uster]
I refrayned to use
e name of her Ma
ty
, w
ch
their
LL. I hope will interpret to
e best, & signif[ie]
theyr pleasure for proceeding heerafter. The [last]
letter from you that I have receaved was of
e [18]
of Ja
n
. Wherto I do not doubt, but my forme[r]
answeres have satisfied yo
r
L.
& so I take my h[umble]
leave. Hage Fe
b
25 1591.
